bad.work: The Poetical Works of Geoffrey Chaucer, 1783

title.reg: The Poetical Works of Geoffrey Chaucer, 1783

titlestmt.title: The Poetical Works of Geoffrey Chaucer, 1783 : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 13KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 150KB to 410KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries April 2023
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a Chaucer Omnibus, a selection of seven works by Blake on the subject of Geoffrey Chaucer.
The Archive has previously published works by Blake that are of a Chaucerian nature; these include five pages in the Notebook, Objects 58, 67, and 119–21, in Manuscripts and Typographic Works, the tempera painting of Sir Jeffery Chaucer and the Nine and Twenty Pilgrims on their Journey to Canterbury, in Drawings and Paintings, and all four states of the engraving of the painting, in Separate Prints and Prints in Series. Both the engraving and painting can also be viewed in a multi-gallery presentation in Archive Exhibitions. The exhibition includes works in the Omnibus that are now also accessible in their genre categories:
Blake’s Chaucer: The Canterbury Pilgrims, 1809, a single page prospectus for the engraving of his painting, which he refers to as a "Fresco Picture."
Blake's Chaucer: An Original Engraving, 1810, an advertisement for and three-page leaflet describing the engraving.
Exhibition of Paintings in Fresco, Poetical and Historical Inventions, 1809, an advertisement for Blake's exhibition with a one-page text on "The Invention of a portable Fresco," dated May 15, 1809 (in pen and ink). The sheet was folded to make an envelope addressed to "Ozias Humphry, Esq. / Sloan Street." Blake had enclosed "a ticket of admission" to his exhibition and a short letter asserting that "Florentine & Venetian Art cannot exist together," claims he expounds upon in the exhibition’s Descriptive Catalogue, which includes Blake's lengthy description of his Chaucer painting.
These works are now available for study in Manuscripts and Typographic Works, as is the Descriptive Catalogue.
Another work in the Archive's digital exhibition on Chaucer now accessible in its genre category of Drawings and Paintings is
The Canterbury Pilgrims: Sketch for the Engraving, 1809, a pencil drawing based on the painting but reducing its size to that of the engraving.
The Omnibus also includes two works in Commercial Book Illustrations:
An engraving after a design by Stothard, dated March 1783, that served as the frontispiece to volume XIII of The Poetical Works of Geoffrey Chaucer in Bell’s Edition [of] the Poets of Great Britain.
The Prologue and Characters of Chaucer's Pilgrims Selected from his Canterbury Tales, which comprises a frontispiece, dated Dec 26, 1811, and a tailpiece. The former reproduces, at a much reduced size, a portion of the left side of the large engraving; the latter is a vignette of Canterbury Cathedral.
Also included in the Omnibus is a
portrait of Chaucer from the series of Eighteen Heads of Poets that Blake painted in watercolor and pen and ink for William Hayley's library, c. 1800-1803, and now in the Manchester Art Gallery. It is the first of the series in the Archive (to be joined by the others in due course) and can be found under Drawings and Paintings.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: Apollo Press printer of the letterpress text

objinfo.printdate: 1783The title-page of Volume XIII is dated 1782, but the table of contents is dated 22 March 1783 and Blake's frontispiece is dated 24 May 1783, thus the real date is 1783.
objinfo.framelines: A single framing line extends around the image, excluding the colophon.
objinfo.binding: full calf binding This page is bound as the first leaf in the volume before the title-pages.

provenance.name: Robert N. Essick
provenance.note: Early history unknown; acquired in 1972 by Robert N. Essick from the Los Angeles dealer Zeitlin and Ver Brugge Books as part of 102 volumes of *Bell's Edition [of] The Poets of Great Britain*, $623.74 for the set.
The set acquired by Essick is incomplete, as it contains only 102 volumes of the 109 volume set.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Pictured in an oval frame in the center of the plate, a resting figure — almost certainly Samson — lies unconscious and limp on the ground. He is muscular and bare-chested, and wears a cloth or loincloth around his waist. His body faces left, and his face faces forward and tilts slightly to the right. His head, with curly hair, rests against his bare left shoulder. His eyes are closed. His left arm bends ninety degrees at elbow so that his clenched fist rests on his lap, while his right forearm extends over his right thigh. One finger of his right hand is pointed, as the hand drapes over his inner thigh. Samson's upper body is propped upright against the legs of a woman standing behind him. This woman is most likely Delilah. She wears a gown with a bodice or vest over her torso and has dark hair that is pulled into a bun. She bends forward and reaches her left arm downward to support or hold up the unconscious Samson. Her left hand is held behind his back. Her head, turned to look behind her, is encircled with a strip of cloth. She may be blindfolded. A group of three men stand behind her. These figures may be the “fooman” in “The Monk's Tale,” to whom Delilah sells Samson. The central figure in the group wears the uniform of a Roman solider, including a helmet and tunic. His body faces forward and his legs are spread apart, with the left leg extended to the left and the right leg bent at the knee (although it is mostly obscured by Delilah's dress). He twists his upper body to the right, and bends his right arm upward at the elbow to cross over his chest. His face is turned downward and to the left to look at the ground or, perhaps, at Samson. A cloak or cape billows from his back to his left, and it may be worn by him or by the figure to his right. To the right of the central figure, a man with long white hair looks downward and to the right. His body faces right, and his left arm extends outward to grab a curtain, visible at the edge of the frame. Only his upper body is visible, but he appears to wear a tunic similar to that of the central figure. To the left of the central figure, a third figure, likely a male with long dark hair, faces the right. His upper body and face are obscured by the central figure, so that only his legs are visible. His legs are spread, with one leg extended backward and the other bent at the knee, as if he is lunging. He appears to wear a tunic similar to that of the central figure. A column is visible behind and to the left of the figures, and they appear to stand or lay on a hard floor. A curtain or drapery extends from the top of the oval frame to the lower third of both sides. The oval frame sits within a backdrop that appears to be of bricks. Above the oval frame, there is a stone or marble plaque. Below the plaque, there is the statue or sculpture of the head of a figure, perhaps a female. Her long curly hair extends to either side, and from both sides of hair two pieces of cloth or drapery extend, draped to the sides and upward, where it hangs over two hooks on either side of the plaque. The ends of the cloth twist over itself to form two loops on either side. A second plaque sits below the oval frame.

component.illusobjdesc: Pictured in an oval frame in the center of the plate, a resting figure — almost certainly Samson — lies unconscious and limp on the ground. He is muscular and bare-chested, and wears a cloth or loincloth around his waist. His body faces left, and his face faces forward and tilts slightly to the right. His head, with curly hair, rests against his bare left shoulder. His eyes are closed. His left arm bends ninety degrees at elbow so that his clenched fist rests on his lap, while his right forearm extends over his right thigh. One finger of his right hand is pointed, as the hand drapes over his inner thigh. Samson's upper body is propped upright against the legs of a woman standing behind him.

A woman, most likely Delilah, stands behind Samson. She wears a gown with a bodice or vest over her torso and has dark hair that is pulled into a bun. She bends forward and reaches her left arm downward to support or hold up the unconscious Samson. Her left hand is held behind his back. Her head, turned to look behind her and away from the viewer, is encircled with a strip of cloth. She may be blindfolded.

A group of three men stand behind Delilah. These figures may be the “fooman” in “The Monk's Tale,” to whom Delilah sells Samson. The central figure in the group wears the uniform of a Roman solider, including a helmet and tunic. His body faces forward and his legs are spread apart, with the left leg extended to the left and the right leg bent at the knee (although it is mostly obscured by Delilah's dress). He twists his upper body to the right, and bends his right arm upward at the elbow to cross over his chest. His face is turned downward and to the left to look at the ground or, perhaps, at Samson. A cloak or cape billows from his back to his left, and it may be worn by him or by the figure to his right.

A group of three men stand behind Delilah. These figures may be the “fooman” in “The Monk's Tale,” to whom Delilah sells Samson. To the right of the central figure, a man with long white hair looks downward and to the right. His body faces right, and his left arm extends outward to grab a curtain, visible at the edge of the frame. Only his upper body is visible, but he appears to wear a tunic similar to that of the central figure.

A group of three men stand behind Delilah. These figures may be the “fooman” in “The Monk's Tale,” to whom Delilah sells Samson. To the left of the central figure, a third figure, likely a male with long dark hair, faces the right. His upper body and face are obscured by the central figure, so that only his legs are visible. His legs are spread, with one leg extended backward and the other bent at the knee, as if he is lunging. He appears to wear a tunic similar to that of the central figure.
The background is scarcely detailed, but there is a visible column behind and to the left of the figures. They appear to stand or lay on a hard floor.
A curtain or drapery extends from the top of the oval frame to the lower third of both sides.
The oval frame over backdrop or façade that appears to be made of bricks. The oval frame casts a slight shadow over the bricks.

Above the oval frame, there is the statue or sculpture of the head of a figure, perhaps a female. Her long curly hair extends to either side, and from both sides of hair two pieces of cloth or drapery extend, draped to the sides and upward, where it hangs over two hooks or posts on either side of a plaque. The ends of the cloth twist over itself to form two loops on either side.
Two plaques, which may be made of marble or stone, are positioned above and below the oval frame. Each plaque contains a frame, within which text is engraved.

lg.l: London Printed for John Bell British Library Strand May 24,th 1783.
